There are no Lobsters nor Crabs, but a great abundance of fish of all kinds; one, the Salmon of the English, or Carwai (Carwhy), is a most excellent fish, the best I have tasted in the Southern Hemisphere; ...

Author: POLACK
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] paraua [a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Salmon, n . The English Salmon is being acclimatised with difficulty in Tasmania and New Zealand; the Trout more successfully. But in all Australian, New Zealand, and Tasmanian waters there is a marine fish which is called Salmon; it is not the true Salmon of the Old World, but Arripis salar , Gunth., and called in New Zealand by the Maori name Kahawai . The fish is often called also Salmon-Trout. The young is called Samson-fish (q.v.).

Author: MACLEAN
Quote: [John Pascoe] appreciated fitness, though not speed, and above all he appreciated relaxation, especially sunbathing. To promote this concept he coined the term 'to salube', which soon became synonymous with his name and has become part of Tararua folklore.

To offset these rather gloomy expressions there are those that derive from salubrious. They are J.D. Pascoe terms and were brought by him from Canterbury to Wellington. They obviously arose from the habit of describing sunny, pleasant weather or places as `salubrious'. First is the salubrium , a rest or sunbake in salubrious conditions. This first appeared in The Tramper in 1937. About 1939 people were salubriating , or taking a salube in the sun. The previous year Te Matawai was described as a `salube hut'. By 1943 trampers were sunbathing and salubing . So far as Tararuas are concerned, salube as a noun and a verb is the word that has survived.
Notes: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 28

Whatever happened to those `sandpaper suits?' - the khaki shorts and battledress tunics worn by thousands of boys during the heyday of the school cadets. MANAPOURI stickers seem to come in a number of different forms. There is the common "Save Manapouri," a simple plea from the heart. "Help Save Manapouri," a call not to be just sympathetic but do something about it. Then there is "I Want to Save Manapouri," a pitiful cry by someone who feels impotent to do anything. But my favourite is the cynic's sticker indicating that he is tired of the whole business: "Drain Manapouri."

Author: Roger WILSON
Quote: The turning point of the opposition to the raising of the lake came when a crowded and lively public meeting was held in Invercargill on 30 October [1969]. As a result of that meeting, the first "Save Manapouri" committee was set up. Similar groups were quickly established in other centres around the country.
The movement to "Save Manapouri" is a case book example of how trends are adopted in a democratic society.

The Save Manapouri campaign has been lauded as "the birth of the modern conservation movement" in New Zealand. The Save Manapouri campaign began in the late 1950s with the proposal to build a power station to supply power to an aluminium smelter in the far south of New Zealand and gained momentum in the 1960s when it was proposed that the level of Lake Manapouri would be raised 8.2 metres to harness its hydro-electric potential for the project.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (marbles) Ibid. 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899: reference, game of Little Ring] Many heated arguments arose as to who said `everythings' or `nothings' first. If a player's `taw' touched a marble and lay alongside it, the others would shout `knuckle down' just before his turn. ... `Knuckle down' meant that the player had to hold his taw close to the marble attacked and fire it in that very inconvenient position. ... When a boy lost all his marbles at play he was `scat' [?related to skint ?HWO] . ... A `ringer' was a taw which, when fired at the commencement of the game, lodged in the track of the ring itself; that, and knocking a marble out when he `fired' were the perfect shots. ... To fire a shot while holding the hand nearer to the ring than where the taw had lain, was to `funk', an unforgiveable crime.

The schedule rate itself varies throughout the year, depending on the supply and on the overseas demand for beef.

Culled dairy cows and culled beef animals are sent directly to the works as `boners' - that is, the bones are removed from the carcasses and the meat is used for manufactured products (as distinct from meat that is used for prime cuts). Farmers are paid schedule rates on the killing weights.

Bellamy's menu has qualified as the most snobbish of all State papers. Whenever the well-known New Zealand fish called snapper is an item of Parliamentary diet it is invariable [sic] spelled `schnapper.' The gourmets of the Food and Wine Society could be forgiven for such literary heresy, but the old prosaic spelling should be good enough for the dining-room in Parliament House. Incidentally, the legend is that the fish was given the name `snapper' by Captain Cook when he was here on his voyage of exploration in 1770. As he and the members of his crew leaned over the side of their galleon two centuries ago and threw their fishing lines into the waters off the New Zealand coast the fish used to snap at the bait. Hence the name snapper.

My reference in last week's column to the snobbishness of Bellamy's in using the spelling `schnapper' when that fish was on its menu has brought `bites' galore - from fish merchants to schoolmasters. Most of them, it is fair to say, have taken up the cudgels on behalf of Bellamy's, but none of them has disproved my argument that the correct spelling is `snapper.' ... Some historians support my Captain Cook theory, though there are others who place the first use of the name `snapper' at a later date, certainly not earlier. They think the name may have been given the fish by Captain W. L. Edwardson, the commander of a New South Wales Government cutter called the Snapper which was in New Zealand waters in 1822 and 1823 investigating sealing prospects. He gave the name Port Snapper to an inlet on Ruapuke Island in Foveaux Strait. Whatever the origin of the word, the fish served at Bellamy's is indigenous to New Zealand and is spelt `snapper.'

The fishing off the island is very good, there being abundance of hapuku, kohikohi, maumau, schnapper, kahawai, tarakihi, in addition to plenty of shell-fish such as koura or cray-fish, crabs, paua,etc.

The name `Greymouth Schooner' is not the name of a ship but the designation given to a drinking vessel which is supposed to have a capacity of an imperial pint, or 20 ounces- double the size of the ordinary glass. West Coasters are inordinately proud of their reputation of being able to consume more beer in any given time than those in less favoured parts of the Dominion and support for their contention was forthcoming in the glass that was famed in many a story of the early Coast days as the `Greymouth Schooner' These have almost disappeared from the West Coast hostelries but one has been secured through the generosity of Mr. H.E. Wedde of Oamaru, for the Otago museum. The Museum boasts a particularly fine collection of glassware going back to the days of the early Egyptians and the Director, Dr H.E. Skinner seemed overjoyed that such a famed drinking measure as the `Greymouth Schooner' should find a place in such select company. The claim that the glass provided a full 20 ounces is disputed by Dr Skinner however, who finds that it is only [?] 17.5 ounces.
Notes: 1950 (? 51 ? 52) Evening Star (Dunedin) ca Nov 22; or Feb 23-25; or Feb 15 (R.Mason)

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote: Another discovery was that the word `Scotch' was worked much harder in New Zealand than in Scotland. It might be used with degrees of meaning ranging from praiseworthy frugality to out-and-out niggardliness. It [41] might be: ``A' will make a farm out of that place if anyone can - he's pretty Scotch.' Or it might be `B's' too Scotch to feed his kids properly.' Fortunately I had mastered the new usages when some months later a man gave me his views on parsimony as a Scottish characteristic. `They talk about the Scotch,' he said. `I reckon that a really scotch Englishman is as scotch or maybe scotcher than any Scotchman.'

Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.

The best kind of flax was the Tihore. The native plan of preparing it was very simple. They tore out the fibres, rubbed them together in their hands to open the bundles, and removed the small tissue that remained by scraping it with their nails. The inferior kind they prepared somewhat differently. They scraped it with a shell, having sometimes previously steeped it in water to soften the skin; they then soaked it in water for from two to four days, heated it with stones while it was wet, and scraped it again, then soaked it again, and then bleached it and dried it on poles ...

It is considered necessary to scrape the flax before beating it, in consequence of the coating being chiefly composed of silex, attempting to remove which merely by the process of bruizing [sic] is attended with the destruction of the fibre.

If any word originating in the mountain clubs deserves to be incorporated in the language it is perhaps scroggin. That mixture of raisins, sultanas, chocolate, nuts, boiled lollies, a mixture of bits and pieces of whatever one fancies, was evolved to fill the need for a sustaining, palatable, easily-carried food, one as readily available for a bite snatched in a cold, wet, momentary halt as for a welcome spell in the warmth and sun. The word seems to come from Otago but its derivation is not clear. There is a Scotch and North of England dialect word scrog which refers to stunted bushes, and if some Otago Scot had this in mind it prompts dark thoughts as to what the original comestible may have been like. Perhaps it is one of those words that have no known ancestry, that come out of the blue, such as children sometimes so happily coin.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Scrub, n. country overgrown with thick bushes. Henry Kingsley's explanation (1859), that the word means shrubbery, is singularly misleading, the English word conveying an idea of smallness and order compared with the size and confusion of the Australian use. Yet he is etymologically correct, for Scrobb is Old English (Anglo-Saxon) for shrub; but the use had disappeared in England.

Scrub, n. Thicket of shrubs or bushes of too low a growth to be called bush (q.v.). On the plains it usually grew in belts or patches. The best known components in Canterbury are Manuka, Wild Irishman, Miki-miki (of which the shepherds make walking sticks), and Moutain pine (Totara nivalis). A single plant of scrub is called a bush, while of course a single specimen in the bush is a tree. Perhaps (if the question couldn't be settled by species) ten feet would be the dividing height between s. and b.

Author: POLACK
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para [as-acute] paraua [a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

pa[a]ua, a shellfish (Haliotis iris); there are three species (H. rugusoplicata and H. virginea also) but iris is much the most common, and is the one with the red-blue-green opalescence that has made it so popular for use as ornaments, etc., within the last few years: it was exported from the beginning of settlement for the making of buttons, but a rage has set in for the wearing of paua jewellery and the use of paua small goods, ink-stands, serviette-rings, etc., and a new name has been given to it - sea-opal, and its deeper tints are as beautiful as opal if not as durable. The exportation of the shell has now been prohibited, but not the exportation of the manufactured article, so that Newzealand has acquired a distinctive industry

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: SEAPERCH (POHUIAKAROA) JOCK STUART, HIGHLANDER, FIVEFINGER, SOLDIERFISH or SCRODDIE Helicolenus papillosus (Bloch and Schneider) The seaperch is a fish well known to all fishermen both sports and commercial fishermen alike, who give it quite a number of vernacular names, a few of which are as follows: Jock Stuart, Highlander, Fivefinger and Soldierfish. These names have a bearing on some distinguishing characteristic of the fish. For instance the first two names are supposed to be given on account of the colouring of the fish resembling, in some ways, the tartan of a Scot; while Fivefingers is given on account of the so-called five (really more) fingers (rays) of the pectoral fins, on which the fish has a habit of resting on the floor of the aquarium tank. The name Soldierfish is derived from the similarities of this fish to the activities of a soldier or picket on sentinel duty. I have often seen Seaperch stand or, rather, rest at attention on its pectoral fins for lengthy periods. When it did move, it moved to the right or to the left with the precision of a well-trained soldier. The name Scroddie, commonly used at the northern end of the South Island, is derived from the word Scrod which means a young Dogfish. It appears from my researches that when the early colonists first saw a small Seaperch they at once named it Scrod and later the `ie' was tacked on to make Scroddie.

Anyone who had ever been about old whaling and sealing stations must have seen collections of round smooth stones of various sizes but mostly about the size of cannon-balls, lying on the beach. On asking any of the `old hands' what these are, you will at once be told that they are `seal's ballast' ... You will probably be gravely told that the seal is a migratory animal, and that when it is about to take a long journey it will trim itself to exactly the proper weight for long and easy locomotion through the water. It picks up one of these stones and swallows it and goes into the water to try the effect. If it finds it requires more ballast it comes ashore again and repeats the dose. If it has too much weight .... it vomits one or two of the stones out on the beach. Hence the stones are always termed `seals' ballast'

[fn] The terms dust, seeds, chips, nubs, &c., are the names given to certain of the lower kauri gum grades according to the relative sizes of the pieces. From `dust' the size of the fragments increases in the order given, as does also the purity of the grade. Chalk, or `chalky gum,' is a particular grade recovered from swampy country and is characterized by its white or chalky appearance and large water content.

Another form of gambling ... is that known as `selling a horse' ... A member of the party thinks of, or writes down a number and another member starts counting, beginning at any number below ten, and the party takes it in turn to count, much as in the Army a platoon is numbered off. The member saying the number thought of or written down collects the pool.

Author: BELTON
Quote: The procedure is sometimes referred to as `selling a horse' Each person pools so much money and a number is written down and hidden from view. The person who writes a number down requests one of the others to start counting, commencing at any number desired, provided that it is lower than the winning number. The counting is then carried on in rotation and stops when the written number is reached. The winner then takes the pool and pays for whatever has been purchased ....

Another form of gambling which I view much less harshly is that known as `selling a horse.' The process is as follows. A member of the party thinks of, or writes down a number and another member starts counting, beginning at any number below ten, and the party takes it in turn to count, much as in the Army a platoon is numbered off. The member saying the number thought of or written down collects the pool. This game, though coming under the heading Games of Chance is probably the one really honest game in that category. I myself usually win it, especially in parties where there is no one with a pencil and I think of the number.

Amazing, the words people find buried in unlikely websites. Geoff Sommerville was browsing through Papers Past last 19th-century section of the National Library's site, and chanced on servantgalism. He reports the context told him it was a term for servants who got too big for their boots. Servantgalism, and its male equivalent flunkeiana, were slang words in use in colonial Australia when servants were hard to come by. Melbourne Punch in 1861, for instance, ran a cartoon of a prospective employer offering to drown a few of his children to accommodate a maid who found looking after seven would be too much.

A cross between a taxi, bus and freight truck, these big cars plied their trade on country roads gathering together the various threads of rural society. In a letter dated 8th March 1850, in mentioning a visit to the Taieri Plain, the writer says: "We visited the warri or hut of a Shaproon - ie., one of the retired whalers 'who have married Maori wives.' Can you tell me the meaning and derivation of the word Shaproon, and why the retired whalers were so called?" Ibid 22 September. 24 Shaproon is from the French chaperon, and originally meant "little captain." ..There is no doubt that the term was used by French sailors and those in contact with them with the same meaning as English sailors use the word mate. Mispronounced and misspelt by its adoption into the English of rough-and-ready sea-faring men, shaproon would have this signification, and even under certain circumstances might reassume its original acceptation of little leader, and be addressed to the captain of a small band, and become equivalent in a new country, as this was 50 years ago, to the word pioneer.

The term `Shagroon' was used to describe pastoralists and stock-drivers who came to Canterbury direct from Australia and without the blessing of the Cby. Association. The Cby Assoc. settlers were `Pilgrims', while those established in Canterbury before their arrival were `pre-Adamites'.
A term formally used for a settler in Canterbury, New Zealand, who came from Australia or anywhere but Britain.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: A term peculiar to early Canterbury is shagroon, for Australian squatters invading that province.

Author: WALL
Quote: Who first called these immigrants by this opprobrious name is not stated, but it seems to me most probable that the Pilgrims used it as a term of contempt, and [110] that the immigrants took it to themselves much as the `Old Contemptibles' ... adopted their enemies' names in a spirit of defiance. ... There arises the further question as to the origin of the word which ... has been explained as an Irish `shaughraun'. Now why should an Irish word have been used at that time by the English settlers in Canterbury? ... My belief is that the word was not originally `Shagroon' but `Shabroon', `shabberoon', `shabbaroon' (all spellings occur) which is on record from the 18th century onwards, meaning `a mean, shabby fellow', `a disreputable or mean-spirited fellow', and this, which would be probably familiar to the English Pilgrims, is just the sort of term which would naturally be used to describe their rivals. This `shabroon' derives from the slang `shab', a low fellow, recorded as early as 1637, and no doubt closely alied to the standard `shabby', and ultimately from `shab' and `scab', two forms of the old English word. ... I conjecture that the `shabroon' [?does Wall mean `shagroon] of the English Pilgrims was by some pronounced with the `b' and by others with the `g', nobody ever having seen the word written or printed. [EDD records only `shaggareen' from east Yorkshire `an untidy, slovenly person'; possibly f. shabrag]
Notes: 1948 Nov 25 Arnold Wall letter in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 109-110

Author: REED
Quote: It appears to have been the Australian squatters [let in to Canterbury by Godley to provide capital and flocks for unsold land] who jocularly termed the pioneer English settlers the `Canterbury Pilgrims', ... Shagroon.- The Australian squatters who invaded Canterbury in 1851-(2) We probably owe most of the Australian sheep farming terms and practice we have here to them. They always spoke of coming down (not over) from Australia. They were also called prophets(q.v.). (C.R., p. 8; [1898 Morris Austral-English], which derives ss. from Irish Shaughraun.)

Author: MORRIS
Quote: When the province of Canterbury, in New Zealand, was first settled, the men who came from England were called Pilgrims, all othersShagroons, probably a modification of the Irish word Shaughraun.

shagroons ... n. in N.Z. early settlers at Canterbury.

Author: THOMSON
Quote: ...An old Australian squatter, who visited the Canterbury settlement in 1851, divided the inhabitants into pilgrims, shagruns, and prophets; the first were the original colonists, the second were people from other parts of New Zealand, and the last were settlers from Australia.
The pilgrim toiled for his crop. ... Shortly the pilgrim and prophet agreed The plough and the crook couldn't live far apart.
Notes: [1851] 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 5, 9, 125 `Pilgrims and Prophets'. [title of Poem] 9.[NOTE 1866] 125. During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria) who were regarded by the settlers partly with admiration as successful Colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonisation and the `Canterbury System'. The visitors found the country admirably adapted for sheep-farming, and they treated with some contempt the raw emigrants from England who looked to agriculture as the foundation of their fortunes. One of the vistiors, who seem to have delighted in the soubriquet of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter, which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined and their country left for occupation by his more enlightened comrades. The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nickname their Port Philip visitors `prophets' and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. The Canterbury pasturage system was quickly adapted to the requirements of sheepfarming on a large scale, and `pilgrims' and `prophets' were soon merged into one class of Canterbury runholders.

Author: PRATT
Quote: In the `Dream of a Shagroon' which bore the date Ko Motinau, April 1851, and which first appeared in the `Wellington Spectator' of May 7th, the term Pilgrim was first applied to the settlers; it was also predicted in it that the `Pilgrims', would be `smashed' and the `Shagroons' left in undisputed possession of the country for their flocks and herds.

This was carried out principally by stock owners from Australia, who, to distinguish them from the Pilgrims or those who came from England direct to Canterbury, were called Shagroons. What this title is derived from is not quite clear. The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. The latter, with a motion like cracking a whip, gets rid of as much rubbish as possible, after which he places the hank handy for the `washer'. The native whare[e-grave] of thatch is quickly and easily raised, serves all requirements, and lasts for years ... A shanty here, is a name applied to almost any kind of nondescript erection, which would not come under the designation of [117] whare[e-grave], or be honoured by the ambitious title of house. Author: BACON
Quote: sharemilker-One who contracts to milk a herd of cows for a share of profits. In general, sharemilkers fall into three categories: first, the 29 per cent sharemilker, second, the 39 per cent man, third, the 50 per cent man. The 29 per cent man contracts to milk the farmer's herd and attend to their wants only; he helps at haymaking, etc. as part of the herd's `wants', but in general, once the cows have been attended to for the two daily milkings, his time is his own. The 39 per cent man contracts to milk the herd owned by the farmer and to do all the other general farm work. For this he receives 39 per cent of the herd profits. The 50 per cent sharemilker runs his own herd of cows on another man's land. He does all the farm work, and receives 50 per cent of the profits. Many farmers who today have their own farms in New Zealand started off as 39 per cent share milkers, saved enough to buy their own herds and so became 50 per cent milkers, then saved again to purchase land themselves (or on which they put sharemilkers!)

A feature of dairy-farming in New Zealand has been the development of share-milking, akin to the old French system of me[acute]tayage or the sharefarming common with annual crops such as cotton in the United states of America. Under this system the owner usually provides the land, plant, and herd, while the share-milker provides labour and receives in return one-third to one-half of the gross returns. In other cases the sharemilker also provides the dairy herd and receives two-thirds of the gross receipts.

Sir, - I read `The Dominion's' second editorial of Jauary 25, `Our `She'll-Be-Right' Attitude,' with interest, but as a Grim Dig I feel that it is my duty to point out to the younger generation the origin and meaning of the expression `she's right' `She's right' or `She'll-Be- Right' originated in the Army and was only used when the person using the saying was satisfied that he had done his particular job to the best of his ability and took pride in it. If, on the other hand, he had done the job to the best of his ability but he was not satisfied with the job, he used the phrase `She's not too good' or `She's pretty poor' Never was the phrase `She's right' used in the sense that politicians and various other people not in the know use it to refer to a job badly done or done with a `couldn't-care-less' attitude. This was never necessary because in the Army we had other phrases to cover such contingencies when things did not go according to plan, such as NAFU and SAFU, the first being a non-adjusting fiasco, and the second being a self-adjusting fiasco. To say the least of it, I feel strongly that it is disrespectful to the originators of the saying `She's right' to use it in the present accepted sense, and I feel also that all Grim Digs should rise up in righteous wrath, but `don't do your scone boys.' Belmont. INFANTEER.
she's right: popular term to say that everything will be alright in the end; e.g., `She'll be right mate, don't worry about it.'

Shearer.- One who shears (and while so employed does nothing else). Ss., who always work in company and generally stick to the work for years, meet a great many people and see a great many stations; so they have a great store of expressions connected with their work. Some of them have already been noted (rosella, cobbler, etc.) If two ss. are working out of sight of each other, they can tell one another `where they are' (what part of the sheep they are on) to an inch. A shearer first shears the belly (on the b.), then opens up or goes up the neck, then successively does his first leg, first side, up the back, and so on; finally the last blows trim the last leg, and he is off. But they also use a rhyming slang sometimes among themselves; say, `found a nail' for `round the tail', `hutch' for `crutch', and so on. I have always meant to collect these terms but never have. (C.)

Quote: There is a danger of all writers about the old days using modern terms which were not used in the period they are writing about. .... But some older writers make some surprising slips, and a really noticeable instance is in the inscription in the porch of the Memorial Church at Cave, South Canterbury, which reads: `This porch is erected to the glory of God in memory of the sheep-men, shepherds, bullock-drivers, shearers, and station-hands who pioneered the back-country of this province between the years 1855 and 1895' When I first read this inscription, the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., flock-owners, flock masters, pastoralists, run holders, run owners, sheep owners, sheep holders, sheep masters, squatters, station holders, station owners, stock holders and stock owners. The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial ..... Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `run holder' was the most used.

Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.

Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.)

So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... Author: BEATTIE
Quote: The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.' Ibid. 12 . provisions became `rations' ... when served out to the man at the `shepherds' huts' (or out-stations).

Vy you tell me dere vos gold now! 'Te's von shicer.

Shi'.cer (sh&imacr.'.s&etilde.r), n. 1. (Mining) A mine which, on being worked, proves to be worthless; - called also a duffer. 2. A man who does not pay debts of honor. [Slang] 3. A worthless or contemptible person.[Slang]
... the terrace ground of Shicer Gully

Author: HOPEFUL
Quote: [Colonial slang] If a man isn't `up to the mark' he is called `a regular shicer!' This phrase originated from the gold diggings. Supposing a man is digging, but without success, and he therefore abandons his hole, it is called a `shicer' - that is, the ground was called a `shicer' or duffer, thus the origin

Author: PFAFF
Quote: On one occasion [they] caused a rush to Lake Brunner, which turned out a `shicer'.
shicer n. unproductive mine or claim; swindler, crook or racecourse welsher

Author: MAY
Quote: DUFFER: applied to a rush, a shaft, or a claim generally. A failure. Synonyms were `shicer', `stringer' or, in the case of a false rush, `store-keepers' rush'. A claim which was exhausted was said to be `duffered out'. At Ross in 1866 putting down a duffer shaft was termed `sinking for the Queen'. Duffers (Creek) is a common West Coast place-name.
shicer n. unproductive mine or claim; swindler, crook or race course welsher

Author: HEINZ
Quote: CLAIMS Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as `tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known as `wages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as `pilers'; the richest of all were known as `Home-ward-bounders.'
shicer n. NZ & Austral. unproductive mine or claim; sl. swindler, cheat. [G scheisser contemptible person] -->b. (? hence) anything useless or worthless

Author: BATHGATE
Quote: Miners' Expressions: ... There are many words and phrases current peculiar to the mining population ... Besides [technical expressions] there are words used in general conversation which would not be found in an English dictionary. Such, for example, as `duffer' or `shiser', anything that is useless.

Author: LOCKWOOD
Quote: Yiddish became a main source of Rotwelsch [the cant language of thieves, etc.] In the course of time a number of originally cant words of Hebrew provenance passed into general use in German, though tending to remain at a more or less substandard level. Modern examples are colloquialisms like acheln eat, Chuzpe f. insolence, ... mies ugly, Moos n. money, schicker drunk, schofel trashy. These examples also occur in Standard Yiddish: akhlen (slang), khutspe, ... mies, moes (slang), shiker, shofl.

Author: ROSTEN
Quote: shikker Pronounced SHICK-er, to rhyme with `stick her'. Hebrew: shikor: `drunk1. A drunk. `He's a shikker.' 2. (Adjective) Drunk. `She got a wee bit shikker.' ... [349] Shikkered, to mean `drunk,' is commonly used in Australia [Wentworth and F 1960 p.466] How the word got all the way down to the Antipodes I do not know.]
Met a schicker last night.
In the world's wide ways of liquor / Leading downward to the Styx, / Be not like the casual shikker. / Turning home at stroke of six.

Author: MACDONALD
Quote: I do not know exactly how wholesale mercantile business was carried on, but the retail business in the town [?Wellington] was carried on [c1840s] mostly by means of little bits of printed paper, issued by shopkeepers, for from one penny to two or three shillings. This currency went by the general name of `shin plaster'. Ibid. 117 When eggs fell from six silver shillings per dozen to one shilling of `shin plasters', the Hutt, Porirua Road and Karori settlers looked anxious.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote: Shinplasters.- The fact that private traders found it necessary themselves, to issue paper notes in denominations below five shillings suggests that at the outset ... the Fitzroy notes were not issued for values below five shillings. The private paper notes were issued for small change, redeemable mostly in `Five Shillings, in Government debentures.' Both the debentures and the private notes were issued on poor paper, and soon became known as `Government Rags' and `Shinplasters' respectively. The term `Shinplaster' for paper money appears to have come to New Zealand from America, via New South Wales. *[fn] In the latter Colony the issue of paper money of a denomination lower than twenty shillings was prohibited in 1826 to promote the circulation of sterling instead of a colonial currency, and the prohibition was welcomed by the people as `preventing the Colony being inundated with beggarly rags' and dollar and half-dollar notes `used often as a paltry contrivance to evade payment of debt,' vide "The Australian," 19 July 1826. [fn] Various reasons have been given for the origin of this curious term for paper money issued in the forties. The most likely explanation comes from America (p. 650 The Numismatist, 1938), where it is stated that in the good old days post-boys and out-riders, wearing high boots, were required, at times, to pay toll-fees at toll-gates, and in order to facilitate progress they placed paper money or coins in bags in their boot-tops, against their shins - hence the term `shin-plaster.'

Author: HARGREAVES
Quote: The [Governor Fitzroy's (1844)] Debentures, popularly known as `government rags', were given various nicknames such as assignats, `shinplasters', and `flash notes'. All these terms had reference to worthless paper money, some of which had been issued in the past. Assignats was the name given to large amounts of paper money issued in France during the French Revolution, but which depreciated to such as extent to be almost worthless. `Shinplasters' - sometimes written `skinplasters' - had its origin in North America, and again referred to depreciated paper money, while `flash notes' was a popular term in use for any counterfeit money or worthless forged paper money.

Shout, n. to stand treat. (1) Of drink. (2) By transference, of other things. The successful digger used to call passers-by to drink at his expense. The origin may also be from noisy bar-rooms, or crowded bar-parlours, where the man who was to pay for the liquor or refreshment called or shouted for the waiter or barman. When many men drink together the waiter of course looks for payment for the man who first calls or shouts out for him to give him the order. Or is `pay the shout' a variant of `pay the shot,' or tavern reckoning? In its first sense the word has reached the United States, and is freely employed there. [1859]

Shedding is common among hairy sickle-fibres; sometimes all are shed, while occasionally, at the other extreme, all persist, every intermediate condition being found. Many of these fibres are much shorter than any shed hairy sickle-fibres.
When a name for these intermediates is needed, the term "super-sickle" is used.
Fibres of this kind that do not grow after birth are called "baby sickle-fibres."

Other somewhat longer sickle-fibres, it would appear from their length, are shed after growing for just a short time after birth. These are termed "infant sickle-fibres" (Fig 4). Infant sickle-fibres are much less abundant than baby ones. Most sickle-fibres with coarse medulla in the post-natal region sustain this up to some eight weeks after birth. For these it is convenient to use the term "chalky sickle-fibres," from their dull white appearance. Super-sickle-fibres, some with a good deal of medulla in the neck, occasionally remain fine after birth ...
The stoutest of birthcoat fibres, halo-hairs, are almost all shed and the super-sickle-fibres with necks coarser than those of sickle-fibres, shed the more readily.

To sidle , to go around the side or across the face of a hill, is a characteristic New Zealand expression, strange to the Englishman or Australian. The example of 1821 in O.E.D.: `Ye know the footpath sidles down the hill', suggests that something of the New Zealand meaning was not unknown in England, but it cannot have been well known, or mountaineers would not have started to use traverse , both as a noun and as a verb, towards the end of last century. Sidle is well known among high-country musterers. As it is a word most likely to be used in open hilly or mountainous country, one may guess that musterers and up-country people gave it currency, whence it was adopted by mountain club people. If ski-ing had not brought its more or less international vocabulary with it we should no doubt be sidling slopes, on skis, that we now traverse... From 1936 to 1938 in The Tramper there are a number of references to `sidling tracks' and `sidling routes'. Towards the end of 1938 comes `after sidling round the head of the said stream', and, a year later, `we sidle the top of Three Johns', and from then on the verb flourishes. In 1940 comes `on a long sidle', and from then on the noun is as common as the verb. Ibid. 41 From the top basin we sidled up tiresome scree, ... and at last emerged on the top of the divide.

There can be no doubt that the so-called broad-nosed eel is the female (local fishermen call it the "glott") and that the sharp-nosed eel is the male, and more popularly known as the "silver-bellied." Snigs, glotts, brotts, and other distinctive names given by eel-catchers are merely varieties, distinguished by colour and other very slight differences, due, a great deal, to environment; all mean one and the same - Anguilla vulgaris.

There are only three fish in the River Avon, sufficiently common to justify the supposition that either of them may be the adult form of the Whitebait; these are the Bull-head, the Silver-fish, and the Smelt. The name of Smelt is applied indiscriminately to the two latter fish, we will ... retain the trivial name of Silver-fish as a distinction. We may first dismiss the Bull-head ... It is an Acanthopterygious fish ... Head, large, one third of the length of the body ... [86] The Silver-fish again belongs to the Malacopterygii abdominales, or fishes having soft fin rays, with the ventral fins placed below the abdomen. ... We now come to the ... fish ...called, by boys, the Smelt; but why a Smelt, I know not. ... the Smelt is a Galaxia ...

Vernacular Name.- Powell [TrNZI 2/84] was the first to point out that two fish were referred to as `smelt' in north Canterbury. These were Galaxias attenuatus and Retropinna retropinna. At present Canterbury residents refer to R. retropinna as `silvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. Maoris refer to this `silvery' as `tikihemi,' and to the adult as `paraki.'

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote: Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy.

Sixty-nine: The shearers' code warning that ladies or visitors are approaching and bad language is out of order - it is intended to sound like some kind of tally.
SIXTY-NINE: The shearers' code warning that ladies or visitors are approaching and bad language is `out of order'.

Author: POLACK
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] paraua[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

Author: BARKER
Quote: ... a constant succession of woolly sheep being brought up to fill the `skillions' (from whence the shearers take them when they want them), and the newly-shorn ones ... being turned out after they have passed through a narrow passage, called a `race,' where each sheep is branded ...

Skillion.- [Variant of 'skillin' and skilling', recorded from the fourteenth century, all late examples being provincial English; origin unknown. --A.W.] In old Australian and New Zealand books (up to about 1880) it is common and means the sheep-holding part of a woolshed. I can remenber an old hand mentioning the word in the 'nineties. I have tried it on several elderly shepherds since the war I and none of them understood it. I imagined the word had gone completely out of use until last month (May 1933), when I bought five tons of chaff from a man and asked him to store it for a few weeks. He looked into his woolshed and said, `Oh yes, there's plenty of room in the skillions.' I felt as if I had met a notornis. ' . . called skillions (whence the name is derived I know not, nor whether it has two l's in it or one). All the sheep go into the skilions.' (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 139). `A constant succession of woolly sheep being brought up to fill the skillions.' ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p. 34).

Quote: The [Governor Fitzroy's (1844)] Debentures, popularly known as `government rags', were given various nicknames such as assignats, `shinplasters', and `flash notes'. All these terms had reference to worthless paper money, some of which had been issued in the past. Assignats was the name given to large amounts of paper money issued in France during the French Revolution, but which depreciated to such as extent to be almost worthless. `Shinplasters'--sometimes written `skinplasters'--had its origin in North America, and again referred to depreciated paper money, while `flash notes' was a popular term in use for any counterfeit money or worthless forged paper money.

The most notable feature of these tests, which extended over nine grazing seasons, including that of 1906, was the remarkable live weight increase furnished by the slagged portions of the field.

The carrying-capacity of the untreated Cockle Park land for the twenty weeks' grazing season was 2 sheep to the acre, which was increased to 4 sheep on the slagged and 2.7 on the superphosphate-dressed plots. Mr G L Marshall .. estimated the carrying-capacity of the slagged paddock as 5.23 sheep.

The relative merits of superphosphate and basic slag for pasture top-dressing are much discussed in certain districts, particularly North Taranaki and North Auckland. Many experienced farmers are firmly of the opinion that slagged pastures have better milk production and fattening capacities than ones treated with superphosphate. How much this may be due to a greater effect from slag, how much to some effect on the mineral content of the herbage, and how much due to management it is impossible to say.
This season the slagged plot was so much improved that it has carried twelve sheep for four months, whereas the untreated plot is much barer with only six sheep.

In some trials made at Cockle Park Agricultural Station the "slagged" soil, which had been longest under treatment, produced - as compared with "unslagged" soil - about 140 per cent. more oats, 30 per cent. more mustard (first crop), 70 per cent. more mustard (second crop), and about 40 per cent. more wheat, the average increase at Cockle Park being 62 per cent.

Every agriculturist knows that it is not customary to place stock on land immediately it has been slagged, but it may be done when the dew has carried the phosphate into the land or immediately after a fall of rain.

Quote: Consider ... the use of the borderline action terms Sleets (Caversham) and Do's (Nth. East Valley) ... meant to overcome a difficulty which sometimes arises in the marble game of Holey. He may then attempt to force the opponent to bring his marble nearer to the hole by the use of the action-term `Sleets'.

Ibid. 169 Slew: To turn or change the direction in which sheep are travelling. To top-side slew is to turn or hunt them downhill. Slewing is done mainly with huntaways and in one of the huntaways events at our trials - Class III - the sheep are hunted on a zig-zag course. This is often called a slew.

Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.)

N.Z. `Slink' In High Demand [heading] ... A coat made from New Zealand `slink' is expected to be shown in the Paris autumn-winter fashion shows, which open here next week. For the uninitiated, `slink' is made from the skins of stillborn lambs. The material is very light and soft, and is highly-prized in the high fashion world of Europe. Each year, apparently, thousands of ewes die before lambing, in the harsh Southland spring. This provides stillborn lambskin which is processed into `slink.' ...

Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote: Smother . If the pens in a woolshed are filled too tight sheep may smother during the night. Sheep are kept in the pens overnight before they are shorn.

Smother.- Run sheep especially merinos, are very easy to s. on broken hill ground. An injudicious turn with a dog in an abrupt gully may stop the lead and cause some sheep to be knocked over. Other sheep make a rush and are brought down too, so that in a second or two there is struggling heap; and before the shepherd can pull them off one another the bottom ones are smothered . They sd. 1200 once on the Stew Point country at Mount Peel, and I believe there was a still worse s . on a station called Roxburgh in Otago. People who fill their woolsheds too tight often smother sheep on a smaller scale: perhaps half a dozen or so in a night. (C.)

Author: BURDON
Quote: Difficulties arose only when they started to go in the wrong direction and had to be stopped, or when a large mob was in hand and a steep, narrow gully had to be crossed; then there was always the danger of a `smother.' Of all breeds the Merino is the easiest to smother, for he moves freer, faster, and more recklessly than any other. If pressed or carelessly handled, some of the leaders may fall or be knocked over and those behind will pile up on top of them until the gully is filled level to the top with struggling sheep.

The islands' only endemic seabird is the Snares crested penguin, which stands a little less than knee high and has a jazzy yellow head-crest, a tangerine-coloured bill, pink feet and smart black-and-white plumage. (A small number of birds display a phenomenon called isabellinism, in which the back feathers are pale fawn).Ibid. 66 [Hdg] Like corks in a maelstrom, Snares crested penguins bob about in the churning surf waiting for a wave to lift them onto shore... Snares crested penguins are one of four species of crested penguins - three of them endemic - which breed in New Zealand waters. All possess a pair of distinctive bands called supercilliary stripes, which run from the bill to the back of the head like giant yellow eyebrows... When the feathers are dry, the bands fluff out to create the classic crested-penguin "punk rocker" look...
These [birds] include the Snares crested penguins, which raise their young in densely crowded colonies from late August to February each year, competing with millions of other seabirds for food.

A radio transmitter recorder ("snark") is placed in the areas where males repeatedly emit their low frequency boom... When kakapo pass a "snark", it detects the radio frequency from each bird's transmitter.

The innovation centres around a portable black box, known as a 'Snark', which contains a radio receiver, data logger and special computer software package. Once placed in the forest, the Snark records the movements of any birds within, say, a 10 metre radius and stores this on its memory. Staff can then come along with a portable mini-computer, plug it into the Snark, and find out what birds have been in the area overnight.

Thus snib exists both as noun and as verb. The little lever on the lock is described as the 'snib', and 'snibbed' is used to describe the state of the lock. To 'snib the door' means to set the lever to lock it; to 'snib it open' means to set the lever to make it unlocked.

Snib is alive and well in Australia, where it keeps doors closed securely. It can be used as a noun referring to the mechanism which works only from one side of a door in a Yale-type lock and fixes the door closed, or to a latch; and as a verb meaning to engage the mechanism or latch.

In the Dee is laid a `strop', a short length of cable with an eye in each end. The eyes are connected with each other and to a short chain by a shackle; and the chain is attached to `the rope' with a hitch.

During that year Tom Thoms, Peter Pringle, and Godfrey Waters snowraked all of Richmond, then crossed the Macaulay River and snowraked Lilybank. Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote: snowrake: to hunt for sheep isolated in deep snow and lead them to safety.

Snowrake.- To rescue sheep from snow and bring them to a safer place. Hence s.raker. (C.)

"The hotel, which is situated about three miles from the top of the pass, has for the past week been crowded with travellers who have got so far on their journey into the Mackenzie Country, but at present can go no further: snow-rakers going up in hot haste to some of the back stations, station-owners who have been down-country for the winter anxious to get through and learn the fate of their stock - all waiting for the first opportunity to make a dash over the pass ..."

The shepherds, in many instances, go prodding about in the snowdrifts with long poles, after the manner of the kauri gum digger using his spear, and if the pole did not strike the sheep, or the snowraker fall through on top of it, he might very easily walk within a foot of it and be unaware of its presence.
The settlers are advertising for snow rakers.

Author: SHARPE

.. we must admire the fine spirit shown by all engaged in one of the most arduous tasks that sheepmen or novices were engaged in, viz., snow-raking.

Author: BARNES

Author: NEWTON

`Snow-raking' - that is, taking sheep from high country ...

These names have a bearing on some distinguishing characteristic of the fish. ... The name Soldierfish is derived from the similarities of this fish to the activities of a soldier or picket on sentinel duty. I have often seen Seaperch stand or, rather, rest at attention on its pectoral fins for lengthy periods. When it did move, it moved to the right or to the left with the precision of a well-trained soldier.

Dogs of every breed, or any breed, "sooners" and others who have as much pedigree as a chicken raised in an incubator, are permitted to roam on the beaches and swim - the latter when some crank throws a stone or a piece of wood in and tells his puerile pup to "fetchit" - where little children are endeavouring to have the time of their lives.

The woolpacks which come down from the country loosely packed and vey imperfectly pressed, are received into the sorting shed, which is fitted up for the accomodation of eleven sorters.

Unskirted wools are legitimately for acquirement by sorters and scourers, those people who after purchase do to the fleeces what the grower should have done, and which he could more easily and cheaply do than the buyer, for when a fleece is taken off the sheep and thrown on the skirting table, what should be taken off, or out, is more easily seen and done than when these fleeces have been rolled up with their imperfections, pressed tight in the bales, and have to be unrolled and properly attended to at a sorter's or a scourer's establishment.

Payment to the sorters for such work generally averages around 1s per pack, but as the reader knows, there are certain large Bradford firms who make standard qualities of tops, which are always so regular that one can buy them without needing to look at any sample.

The South Island kokako is said to have been extinct for the past 30 years, although "missing in action" may be a better description as there have been plenty of tantalising clues to suggest that the bird still exists... the South Island kokako is, or was, about the size of a magpie, with steel-grey plumage and distinctive coloured wattles at the base of its beak. It is a distinct subspecies from its North Island neighbour, which has blue wattles and had avoided extinction thanks to a determined effort by the Department of Conservation. Numerous people have reported hearing the southern kokako, with at least one unofficial sighting, in 1996,near the Glenroy River.

Southerly burster, - buster.- Three-day Sou'Wester. A strong wind with rain, snow or sleet from a southerly direction. The ordinary man in the paddock in Canterbury recognises only three winds: east (from NE), sou'-wester (from SE, S etc, SW, etc.) and nor'-wester. As a matter of fact a t.d.sw .' usually only lasts two and a half. They are said to be less fierce than in the early days, just as the nw. is said to have been softened by the planting on the plains. It may be so in Christchurch but I cannot say I notice any difference up country. The nw . may come from any where between due north and due west. In such places as Hororata, where the wind can get at you down two gorges, a distinction is made between a Waimakariri and a Rakaia nw; but both are called nws . `Where six-days a week the gale/ Laden thick with rain or [hail] First from sou'-west blows a piercer/ Then veers nor'-west and blows fiercer.' In keeping with their commanding presence on the wing, on land southern Buller's albatrosses possess an aristocratic mien. Like several other species small albatross (also known as mollymawks) they have dark shadows under their brows, a crescent of dazzling white feathers behind the eyes, subtle shadings of grey over the head and neck and bright slabs of yellow in the bill. The southern Buller's albatross, Thalassarche bulleri, breeds only on the Snares and Solander Island, off the south Fiordland coast, while a closely related species, the northern Buller's albatross, has its breeding headquarters on the Chatham Islands.

Though by no means faultless, the measure [1846 Constitution Act] seems calculated to be a fair opening to the true history of our great Southern Colony, after the preliminary chapters of tragi-comic blundering. Henceforward, echoed the Colonial Gazette, `the humbug treaty of Waitangi' would be `very properly laid on the shelf'.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game.

Perhaps the most intriguing game of this nature [sc. tormenting insects or animals] is `Spang Weazling'. This game was played at Denniston in 1930-35. A crawley was placed on the end of a stick the middle section of which lay balanced over a stone. Before the crawley could crawl off the stick a stone had to be thrown onto the other end of the stick so as to catapult the crawley off the stick and over the cliff. A variation of the same game was being played at Denniston when I visited there in 1949. It was called alternatively `Hit the Crawley' or `Strike the Crayfish'. In this version the other end of the stick was hit with a batting stick (as in Tip Cat) and when the crawley was catapulted into the air it was hit again with the bat.
Some years ago there was a game among boys [?in Dunedin] called `spangweaselling' - taking kingfishers' nests with the young birds in them and knocking them to bits in the air.
Notes: 1965 Aug 2 WNTV1 `Any Questions' (P. Smithell, Dunedin) [spg SPANGWEASELING]

[Fantastic names of plants] show the imagination running riot; they seem appropriate, though often it is impossible to give any definite reason for the name. ... `Spaniard' [like `Wild-Irishman' is] another name of unexplained origin. There seems even less connection between the human Spaniard and the vegetable spaniard than between the human wild Irishman and the vegetable wild-irishman; and the conjectured corruption `spine-yard', whilst improbable, is no more improbable than the fabled `Bill's-yard' as the origin of `billiard'

Spaniard, speargrass.- Various species of Aciphylla. Plants with stiff sharp leaves like rapiers growing out thickly in all directions from the ground. They were thickest in the hills, but there were plenty on the plains before they were ploughed. Horses avoid them carefully, which makes riding through them unpleasant. There are stories of men falling off and landing on one. Shepherds use the flower stalks for torches when burning. In the 'eighties and 'nineties at Mount Peel they used to all the broader leaved sort Spaniards and the narrower Speargrass; but most people use both names indiscriminately. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) `There is one beast of a plant they call speargrass, or Spaniard.' (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 48).

SPANISH CREAM. - Take three spoonfuls of flour or rice, sifted very fine, the yolks of three eggs, three spoonfuls of water, two of orange-flower water; mix them well together; then put to them one pint of cream, then set it upon a good fire, stirring it till of a proper thickness, and pour it into cups.

SPANISH CREAM - One and a-half pints of milk poured on 1/2oz of gelatine, to soak one hour, three eggs and four tablespoonfuls sugar; beat sugar and yolks together and pour in boiling milk; let it boil one minute, then pour this mixture on whites of the eggs which have been previously well beaten and placed in the mould. Flavour with vanilla. Serve cold with cream.

Author: WEEKES
Quote: A very strange appearance presented itself in the water this morning - streaks of a muddy yellow colour extending for miles. Supposing it to be caused by animalculae I had a bucketful drawn on deck. The water was full of them, having a transparent body with a row of yellow spots round the head. They had long tentaculae, and moved briskly through the water backwards, which motion was effected by ejecting water from two openings situated at the base of the tentaculae. These creatures are generally called [32] `spawn' by sailors; being by them considered the spawn of fish and the food of whales.

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote: I observed in one of the canoes a very singular fish, which the natives call cokiddie, or the spear-fish. It was about the size of a perch, and shaped very like it, except the head, which was rather [23] oblong, like that of a pig; its skin was quite rough, and behind its head nature had armed it with a sharp bone, about two inches long, which it could extrude and draw in at pleasure. It was from this bone that the natives gave it the name of cokiddie, which signifies spear in their language, and therefore appropriate enough.

Hence a `Spear-grass Scrub' on the hill ranges is frequently most formidable ... to men and horses, though it forms one of the favourite hunting grounds of the Wild Pig. In the Matukituki Valley, `Bayonette-grass' forms an undergrowth in a dense scrub of prickly thorn ...

Author: MORRIS

Author: BENNETT
Quote: A spell in New Zealand means a period of rest, rather than of work, and `to have a spell' is to take a rest; in this sense it is probably a remnant of the speech of the New Bedford and Nantucket whalers who once frequented New Zealand waters, `spell oh!' being recorded (in Moby Dick , for example) as a call to cease work or strenuous exercise. [fn.] 15. It is thus much older than `l.C. 19-20,' the date given in Partridge, op. cit., p. 807, and possibly it is many centuries older; cf. The Owl and the Nightingale, l. 258, `lat thine tunge habben spale' where spale is more appropriately translated by `rest' than by Skeat's `turn of work.'

Almost half of New Zealand's reptiles are threatened or endangered. It is now illegal to handle or keep in captivity any native lizard without a permit from the Department of Conservation. Some, such as the spotted skink (Oligosoma lineoocellatum), are still widespread, although their numbers are probably dwindling.
The Landcare Research team has sought answers through an intensive study of two species: the speckled skink Oligosoma infrapunctatum and the green spotted skink Oligosoma lineocellatum.

Spotted skinks also have a scattered distribution indicating that they may once havebeen widespread in lowland areas of the southern North Island south of HawkeBay. Spotted skinks are known from about 10 sites on the mainland North Islandfrom Napier, the Wairarapa and Wellington areas ... In the North Island, spotted skinks coexist with brown, speckled and common skinks.

Author: OLIVER
Quote: The runholder was protected against intruders: cottages, fences and homesteads gave him a pre-emptive right over a set number of contiguous acres. Fences and cottages could be so disposed as to give the runholder rights over the best of the land - sources of water and wood, strips surrounding isolated and thus inaccessible pockets. `Grid-ironing' and `spotting', as these selective practices were called, were certainly used by many runholders to tie up large areas, but probably not to the extent alleged by horrified land tenure radicals in later years.

Author: CRAWFORD
Quote: `Gridironing' was the practice of buying twenty acre sections fronting on a road, so spaced as to leave sections of nineteen acres between them, and as these had to be auctioned the small farmer stood litttle chance of outbidding the run-holder who usually retained them without having to purchase them. `Spotting' was buying up key positions, fertile land, and leaving the barren, water courses, entrances to valleys, road lines, ... .

Author: SCOTTER
Quote: When investigating the change from pastoral lease to freehold in any locality, the student, brought up on Pember Reeves (see e.g. S.E.I. [State Experiments 1902] 234) searches immediately for evidences of the methods by which the runholder retained his grasp of the land. These practices called gridironing and spotting can be defended: there is no need to do so here. If spotting is practiced - the purchase of selected areas with water and shelter for the control this gave over the surrounding country - a study of the Crown grant index maps and of the dates of the original titles supplies no evidence of it.

Author: CARR
Quote: The practice of which I speak is called in New Zealand `spotting' or `spoiling' country. [???a verbal not nominal use]

Author: BAKER
Quote: Spotting was applied to provinces other than Canterbury ... It was probably formed on the basis of the Australian terms pick the eyes out of the country and peacocking.

Author: SINCLAIR

spotting N. in New Zealand selecting the choicest parts of an area, picking the eyes out and leaving the poorer parts. See gridironing.
spotting ... n. in N.Z., selecting the choicest parts of an area, picking the eyes out, and leaving the poorer parts. See gridironing.

So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.

Squat́.ter (-t&etilde.r), n. [Add.] 3 . The owner or occupant of a sheep run; a sheep farmer. In Australia the word had at first the sense of a settler without title; but its use was gradually extended to persons who occupied crown land for sheep raising under a lease or a license, and afterwards to those also who held their sheep runs as freehold. Finally the word became the common name for a sheep farmer, whether occupying leasehold or freehold property. It is, however, giving way to the newer term pastoralist .

There were generally two players ... who each sought to deflect the point of the pocket knife from certain parts of the body by a flick of the hand in such a way that the blade would stick firmly into the ground. ... Every movement had to be done three times. [172] Typical movements were: (1) Place the open pocket knife (loose) [name of movement] [sic] on the closed knuckles of the right hand, point the knife towards the thumb, then with a quick upward flick of the hand to the left, deflect the point of the knife into the ground.

Quote: Stamps: The stamps pulverised the ore after it had passed through the crushers and been reduced to minus-two-and-a-half-inch size. They crushed it to a pulp, with water, until it passed through the 10-mesh (to the linear inch) screens on the mortar-box. There were five stamps (each weighing 1250 lb) to a mortar-box and they operated at 110 drops a minute from a height of 8 ins, crushing approximately 7 tons per 24-hour-day. They were driven by a camshaft, tappets attached to the long stamp stems being lifted in a particular sequence and then the whole weight of the stamp allowed to fall on the ore. Wear of iron was approximately half a pound per ton of ore crushed; the shoes and dies were cast in the Waikino foundry.

IN this sense the word is much used adjectively and in self-explanatory compounds; as, station black, station folk, station hand, station house, station jargon, station life, station property, station keeper, etc. Head station. See HEAD STATION. - Station hut. See HUT, 2. - Station mark, a mark or brand designating sheep or cattle as belonging to a particular station. - Station super, the foreman or manager of a station. See SUPER, 2.
Station: a large farm, usually under extensive farming of sheep and beef.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: originally the house with the necessary buildings and home-premises of a sheep-run, and still used in that sense; but now more generally signifying the run and all that goes with it, Stations are distinguished as Sheep-stations and Cattle-stations.

Station, n. Sometimes sheep s., cattle- s., or dairy-s., (PAUL, p. 68); originally the hut, yards, and buildings where a squatter stationed himself to work his run; but now usually the whole property, including the stock and leasehold country. It has been used in both these senses in Australia (whence the word came) since the 'thirties. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (1) The original sense is still preserved up country, where the men always speak of in at the s., when they are out on the run; also in the word out-s. (q.v.), which has no other meaning than the house, yards etc. (2) The secondary sense of a property with freehold, leasehold, buildings, and stock. (3) Any fairly large property, carrying over 2000 or 3000 sheep. (4) Adjective as in s.horse, belonging to the owner, not to one of the man, whose horses are private; s. sheep, not one belonging to a neighbour; s.-bred, not a bought sheep. (5) Since the 1890s, auctioneers in their advertisements have taken to speaking of s. lines of sheep, though 70 per cent. of those so designated at the autumn ewe fairs come from farms or grazing runs. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])

Author: BEATTIE
Quote: The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late `fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.'

It is usually understood that in the early days the word `station' denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, while `run' meant the whole property. Strange to say, I only noted the word `station' twice, and each time with a diverse meaning. On July 21, 1865, the diary says: `Sold 17 head of cattle - remaining on station 15 head.' Then on September 11, 1865, we read: `Wilkinson returned to the Home Station.' The first of these entries means the whole run - the second the homestead or main buildings.
Notes: 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 115 quoting 1856 July 21 Puketoi Station Diary

Quote: When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.

So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.
